AFG.main:
Assistance needs due to armed conflict and frequent natural disasters include food, healthcare, and protection.? With the increase in the number of people internally displaced by conflict and the influx of returnees from Pakistan and Iran in the year 2016, shelter and WASH needs have increased significantly. 9.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance.?However, the high level of insecurity constrains access.?

INFORM measures Afghanistan’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7.8/10. Afghanistan’s hazard is of particular concern, at 8.8/10.?
AFG.latest_developments_past:
10/07: Flash floods in Badakhshan province have affected four districts. At least four people have been killed and 20 injured. ?

04/07: Continued clashes between ANSF and armed groups in Jowzjan province has further restricted access to health services in Darzab district. The district hospital sustained damage during fighting. ?
AFG.latest_developments_upcoming: Pakistan has extended the deadline for registered Afghan refugees to leave the country to the end of the year 2017.

AGO.main:
The El Niño-induced drought experienced throughout 2016 affected 1.4 million people in Angola, particularly in the southern provinces.?According to INFORM, the risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster is medium, at 4.9/10. The greatest concern is lack of coping capacity, at 7/10.? 

On 24 May Acaps changed the status of the crisis in Angola to No Severity, as its compounding factors were found more related to long-term development issues than acute humanitarian ones. Developments in the country are still being monitored on a daily basis.

BDI.main:
Political instability has crippled Burundi’s economy and driven massive displacement, as people continue to flee violence carried out by both the government and opposition, and their respective supporters. The country has experienced murders, disappearances, kidnappings, torture and mass arrests: more than 9,000 people have been imprisoned since the beginning of the crisis.??Overall, over 423,000 people have fled to neighbouring countries since April 2015. 36% of Burundians refugees fled because of the ongoing sociopolitical crisis, and 63% fled for reasons related to natural disasters.??By the end of 2017, this figure is expected to exceed 500,000.

In addition, deteriorating socioeconomic conditions are driving humanitarian needs for basic health and education services, as well as food, nutrition, and livelihoods support. Over 1,500,000 in are in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) and Emergency (IPC Phase 4).?

INFORM measures Burundi's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster as high, at 6.3/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at concerning levels: 6.1/10, 6.4/10 and 6.4/10 respectively.?

BEN.main: Benin suffered a Lassa fever outbreak in early 2016. For details, see the Special Reports tab.

BFA.main:
Based on ACAPS methodology, Burkina Faso is now considered a situation of concern due to a deterioration of the food security situation driven by the lean season that started in June and will last until September, as well as increased insecurity in the north of the country in 2017.

Over 200,000 people face Crisis (IPC Phase 3) and Emergency (IPC Phase 4) food security outcomes between June and August 2017, up from over 11,000 in IPC Phase 3 between March and May. Northern regions of the country are most affected: the deterioration of the security situation in 2017 resulted in disruption of livestock prices on markets, and increasing staple food prices. 

INFORM measures Burkina Faso’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.4/10.?

BGD.main:
The influx of Rohingya refugees from Myanmar is reported on in an ACAPS briefing note of January 2017.? This report, along with reports of floods in August 2016 are available in the Special Reports tab of this window.

The country is recovering from flooding in July and August, and was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since the beginning of November. The crisis analysis is therefore no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Bangladesh on a weekly basis, due to its high underlying vulnerability and frequency of natural disasters.

BIH.main: Bosnia and Herzegovina was affected by flooding in May 2014. For more information, see our Briefing Note.

BOL.main: Bolivia has been facing a worsening drought situation since October 2015. In August 2016, ACAPS produced a Briefing Note with an overview of current needs in the country.

BRA.main: When Zika virus hit Latin America and the Caribbean in 2015, Brazil was most affected , reporting over a million cases by early February 2016. ACAPS' Briefing Note on the epidemic is available under Special Reports.

CAF.main:
Conflict has resulted in over 500,000 internally displaced people, targeted killings along communal lines, and human rights abuses. Almost half of the population is in need of assistance. Protection, humanitarian access, and food security are priority needs, yet needs continue to exceed available resources. Delivery of aid is expected to continue to decline because funding remains low, and humanitarian access is restricted in large parts of the country.

Since November 2016, fighting among ex-Seleka as well as with anti-balaka in central CAR has resulted in large numbers of displaced, as well as access and protection concerns. Fighting is moving south, with clashes in Haute Kotto, Basse-Kotto, Haut Mbomou, and Mbomou the deadliest since the division of the Seleka faction in 2014.

INFORM measures CAR's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be extremely high, at 8.4/10. CAR's vulnerability is of particular concern.?
CAF.latest_developments_past:
11/07: Due to violence reported at Zemio's hospital, Haut-Mbomou, MSF has withdraw its staff to Bangui. 20,000 people have limited access to health as a result.?

09/07: Fighting in and around Mobaye has displaced 75–90% of 24,500 residents of Mobaye to DRC and remote islands along the Ubangi River, since mid-June.??

05/07: In mid-June, fighting between UPC and local armed groups along the Mobaye-Zangba road (Basse-Kotto) resulted in at least 85 houses burnt down. Between late 2014 and April 2017, at least 4,200 houses have been destroyed in armed clashes throughout the country.??

04/07: At least 22 people have been killed due to fighting between unknown armed groups in Zemio, Haut-Mbomou.  Between 15,000-20,000 people have been displaced and some Congolese refugees, hosted in camp in Zemio, have reportedly fled back to DRC.IDPs are in need of water, shelter, food and health assistance.?? 

01/07: UNHCR and INTERSOS’ bases have been looted by armed men in Kaga-Bandoro, Nana Grebizi. Since the end of May, at least 15 incidents targeting humanitarian actors have been reported in Kaga-Bandoro.?

CHN.main:
A peak in air pollution in December 2016 impacted millions of people across northeast and central China, see our Briefing Note.

Longtoushan township in Ludian county, Yunnan province, was hit by an earthquare in August 2014. 230,000 people were relocated. For details on the immediate impact, see ACAPS Special Reports.

CIV.main:
Côte d’Ivoire is recovering from more than a decade of violent conflict, and the displaced are slowly beginning to return home. The most pressing issue is food insecurity: 76,000 people are are in need of assistance. A high rate of statelessness is a major protection concern and limits access to livelihoods.?? An estimated 700,000 people living in the country do not have any documented nationality.?

Economic improvements and a reduction in food insecurity point to an improving situation in Côte d’Ivoire. Although ranked as a Situation of Concern in the Global Emergency Overview until June 2016, Côte d’Ivoire is now prioritised as a situation of No Severity. ACAPS continues to monitor Côte d’Ivoire on a weekly basis, but updates are no longer regularly posted. It ranks 4.5 on the INFORM Risk Index.?

CMR.main:
Almost 10% of the population in Cameroon is in need of humanitarian assistance, primarily in Far North, North, Adamaoua, and East regions. Conflict in both Nigeria and CAR has led to displacement of refugees to Cameroon. Boko Haram attacks in the Far North region remain regular, with an apparent spike in April 2017. between 55,000 and 60,000 refugees. There has been around 12,000 Nigerian refugees who returned to Nigeria from Cameroon since April 2017. 

INFORM considers that the risk of humanitarian crisis varies widely, from very high in the Far North to very low in western areas of the country. Nationally, the risk is 6.2/10. Hazard and exposure risk stands at 6.8, and lack of coping capacity at 6/10. ?
CMR.latest_developments_past:
10/07: Material damage occurred between 8 and 10 July in Mora, Far North, due to floods. The extent of damage is unknown. It is unclear if shelters were damaged. ?  

07/07: 4,000 Nigerian refugees arrived in Adamaoua and Northwest regions In late July and early July, following ethnic violence between Mambilas farmers and Mbororos breeders in Tabara state. ?

COD.main:
A complex emergency has persisted in DRC for more than 20 years. Conflict is between foreign, self-defence, and other armed groups, and mainly impacting the eastern provinces. Although the security situation has improved slightly since 2013, conflict continues. Access remains volatile in the east, and lack of infrastructure is a general problem across the country. Fighting and insecurity is mostly affecting populations in Sud- and Nord-Kivu, Ituri, Tanganyika, and Haut-Katanga provinces. Since mid-August 2016, the security situation in the Kasai region has significantly deteriorated due to attacks by Kamuina Nsapu militia, and clashes between FARDC and the militia. Health is a priority due to recurrent measles, cholera, and malaria outbreaks, and protection concerns are high. 

A presidential election is due in 2017, and it has been agreed that President Kabila, whose term limit ended in December 2016, will then step down. At least 50 people died in election-related violence in 2016. 

INFORM measures DRC's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 8/10 as well as vulnerability at 7/10.?
COD.latest_developments_past:
12/07: An estimated 57,000 CAR refugees have reportedly fled to DRC since mid-May from Basse-Kotto and Mbomou prefectures due to increased insecurity. Access is limited, especially in Bas-Uele province. ?

11/07: Over 578 suspected cholera cases (CFR:0.7% - 4 deaths) were recorded over 5–11 July. In late June, a lack of drinking water was reported in northern areas of Goma city, Nord-Kivu. ??

10/07: An estimated 80,000 people have been displaced from Fizi territory, Sud-Kivu since late June due to fighting between a new coallition of Mayi-Mayi armed groups and FARDC. They are in need of shelter, WASH, protection and health.?

10/07: Tensions between Hema and Ngiti communities have resulted in the displacement of 3,000 people in Irumu territory since 21 June an. In Djugu territory, tensions between Hema and Lendu communities have displaced 1,500 people since 15 June. First returns of IDPs have already been reported.?
COD.latest_developments_upcoming: Tension and violence are increasing in Katanga area because of the delay in the elections. There are concerns that a crisis, similar to the war of late 1990s, which followed the overthrowing of Mobutu, could take place. ?

COG.main:
Violence in the Republic of Congo erupted in the aftermath of the contested re-election of President Denis Sassou-Nguesso for a third term on 20 March 2016. Amid opposition protests on 4 and 5 April, an attack in the capital Brazzaville, attributed to members of an armed opposition group known as the Ninja militia, resulted in a government-led military crackdown in the Pool department. Located in the south of the country, the Pool department is considered to be a stronghold for the Ninja militia.? The government has severely restrained journalists' and humanitarian organisations' access to affected areas. The opposition accuses the president of committing genocide against the main ethnic group in the country, Lari, who have long been known for opposing the government.?

Severe clashes between government forces and the Ninjas have led to the displacement of thousands of people from affected areas.? Over 60 deadly attacks have been recorded since the beginning of the crisis, in addition to numerous reports of human rights violations, such as killings, torture, and forced disappearances, which continue to emerge and are attributed to both parties.?

In this context of insecurity, legislative elections are scheduled to take place on 16 July.?

COL.main:
The armed conflict between the FARC and the Colombian government lasted for five decaded. At the end of 2016, a peace deal was signed, putting an end to the conflict, and the FARC started the Demobilisation, Disarmament and Reintegration (DDR process). Disarmament was completed at the end of June. However, the deal has not put an end to violence, as other armed groups battle for territory that the FARC is in the process of leaving. Forced displacement and landmine contamination are major concerns. In rural communities, armed group activity restricts movement and limits access to basic health services, as well as access to crops, and labour markets, especially in the Pacific region.

Colombia also experiences frequent natural disasters, particularly tropical storms and heavy rains on the Pacific coast.

INFORM measures Colombia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 at 5.4/10. Hazard and exposure as well as vulnerability are a particular concern, at 6.8/10 and 5.8/10. ?
COL.latest_developments_past: 11/07: An assessment conducted from April to June found a deterioration of living conditions for Venezuelans and Colombian returnees living in 68 settlements in Norte de Santander, as influx from Venezuela has increased since April. Lack of food and diverse diets increases the risk of malnutrition. Limited access livelihoods and education as well as  concerns are reported due to lack of defined rights for these populations.?

DJI.main:
Recurrent and severe droughts over the past two decades have led to a significant deterioration in Djibouti’s humanitarian situation. The population’s coping capacities have eroded, causing rural to urban migration and leaving households unable to generate sufficient income to meet basic needs.

The presence of migrants and refugees has created additional pressure on the state’s limited capacity. There has been an influx of refugees from Yemen since the escalation of conflict in March 2015. Additionally, the country hosts long-term Somali, Ethiopian, and Eritrean refugees, as well as Djiboutian returnees from Yemen, and transiting migrants. 

INFORM measures Djibouti’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster in 2017 to be high, at 5.3/10 up from 4.4/10 in 2016. Lack of coping capacity is of concern, at 6.5/10.? Humanitarian needs are severely increasing as refugee camps are overwhelmed with refugees and migrants.

ECU.main:
On 16 April 2016, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck west of Ecuador’s northern coast. The earthquake left 350,000 people in need of assistance, killed at least 662 people and injured 4,605.? 

INFORM measures Ecuador's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.3/10.? 

By mid-August, Ecuador no longer met the criteria to appear in the Global Emergency Overview. ACAPS continues to monitor the country on a weekly basis, but updates have stopped.
ECU.latest_developments_past: An ACAPS briefing note on the earthquake in Ecuador in April 2016 is available under the Special Reports tab.

EGY.main: Egypt hosts some 120,000 Syrian refugees, and has been covered in a number of reports by ACAPS on the Syria crisis. See Special Reports.

ERI.main:
The Eritrean government severely restricts the access of humanitarian actors inside the country. Very little is known about humanitarian needs: UNICEF estimates that the total affected population is 1.5 million.?UN operations have been restricted to health, water supply and sanitation. An average of 5,000 Eritreans per month are thought to flee the country. Much of the country is affected by recurrent drought, which has been particularly severe over the past year as a result of El Niño.

INFORM measures Eritrea's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be 5.4/10. Eritrea's vulnerability is measured at 4.8/10.

As a proxy for an overall number of people in need ACAPS uses the estimated number of SAM cases. For this reason, Eritrea has been ranked as a ‘situation of concern.’

ETH.main:
A state of emergency was declared on the 9 October 2016 following large-scale anti-government protests, and has been extended until 8 August. The protests started in November 2015, and Ethiopian government forces have killed at least 800 demonstrators in 2016. ? ??

Consecutive, below-average rainy season yields for the Gu (from March to May) and Deyr (October to December) seasons have caused severe drought across northern, eastern, and central Ethiopia.  ? This is leading to high levels of food insecurity, particularly in Afar, in Sitti zone of Somali region, and parts of Amhara, Oromia, and SNNPR. Malnutrition has increased significantly. ? 

Hosting approximately 843,000 refugees from neighbouring countries, including approximately 375,000 from South Sudan, the majority of Ethiopia’s refugee camps have reached full capacity. Overcrowding, malnutrition, and critical shortfalls in humanitarian aid are of concern. Most refugees have been in protracted displacement, but remain in need of assistance.

INFORM measures Ethiopia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.4/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.6/10. ?
ETH.latest_developments_past: 10/07: The rapid spread of armyworms has affected 378,000 hectares of maize cropland, as of 10 July, compared with 49,000 on 19 May.?
ETH.latest_developments_upcoming:
The United Nations meteorological organization said there is a 50 to 60% chance that the Pacific will experience further strong warming this year, which will impact the highlands of Ethiopia. ?

Emergency (IPC Phase 4) food security coniditons are expected in southeastern Somali region due to worsening drought, uncertain aid delivery, and atypical livestock loss. ?

FJI.main: As a result of TC Winston as well as subsequent flooding, Fiji was ranked as a Situation of Concern in the Global Emergency Overview from February to April 2016. Now prioritised as a situation of No Severity, ACAPS continues to monitor Fiji on a weekly basis, but updates are no longer regularly posted. Fiji ranks 3.2 on the INFORM Risk Index.?

GIN.main:
Based on ACAPS methodology, Guinea is now a situation of concern. This is due to a deterioration of the food security situation driven by the lean season from June to September. Over 285,500 people face Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food security outcomes from June to August, up from approximately 109,980 people from March to May.

Humanitarian needs in Guinea spiked in 2014 and 2015, when the Ebola epidemic caused a severe crisis throughout the country.

GMB.main:
Food insecurity is worsening and largely due to crop failure, rising food prices, and loss of livelihoods linked to numerous disasters over the last few years. From June to August, over 111,000 people are estimated to be in Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food insecurity, up from 78,000 people from March to May. The North Bank, Upper River, and West Coast regions are particularly affected. More than 10,000 children under five are severely malnourished. 

Former President Yahya Jammeh, who had been in power for over 22 years, stepped down on 21 January, after a period of instability during which he disputed the result and thousands of people fled to Senegal, in fear of violence. The pre-election period saw unprecedented anti-government protests and clashes with police.

INFORM measures Gambia’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very low, at 3.6/10. Gambia’s vulnerability is of concern, at 5.1/10.

GRC.main: Greece has been the landing-point for hundreds of thousands of people seeking asylum in Europe. ACAPS has produced a number of reports covering the humanitarian needs of migrants and refugees: see the Special Reports tab. For more information, see also the theme page.

GTM.main:
A report on the Northern Triangle from December 2016, on the zika virus in February 2016, and the drought in September 2015 is available in the Special Reports tab of this window. 

Guatemala suffered from drought from 2015- 2016, with over 900,000 people classified as food insecure. This, along with gang-related protection concerns made Guatemala a Situation of Concern in ACAPS' Global Emergency Overview. However, drought effects subsided in the second half of 2016, with only 110,000 classified as food insecure in December 2016. This led to the categorisation of Guatemala as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview. . The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Bangladesh on a daily basis.

HRV.main:
Croatia is one the route taken by migrants and refugees to reach western Europe. ACAPS reports are available under the Special Reports tab. Our theme page provides provides more information on the topic

In May 2014, Croatia was affected by flooding. For more information, see our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

HTI.main:
Haiti is regularly exposed to natural disasters, including hurricanes, floods, earthquakes, landslides, and droughts. The resilience of the population is extremely low, and the political and economic situation is fragile.

Category 4 Hurricane Matthew struck Haiti on 4 October 2016. More than 750,000 remain in need in the most affected areas of Grand’Anse and Sud. The loss of crops due to the hurricane is likely to affect food security throughout the year 2017 for the whole country. ? In addition, 80% of Haiti has been affected by El Niño conditions since the beginning of 2015, and around one million Haitians have been affected by drought. A cholera outbreak has persisted since October 2010.

INFORM measures Haiti's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.5/10. Hazard and exposure is at 5.4/10. Vulnerability and lack of coping capacity are at alarming levels, with rates of 6.7/10 and 7.5/10. ?

IDN.main: Indonesia is suffering an El Niño-related drought, which has led to a food crisis in 2016. See our Special Reports tab for ACAPS analysis of the crisis.

IND.main: In November 2015, several days of heavy rainfall in Tamil Nadu led to flash flooding. At least 29,000 people were evacuated; Cuddalore district was particularly affected. Go to the Special Reports tab to find our Briefing Note on the crisis.

IRQ.main:
In 2014, Islamic State (IS) took over significant portions of Iraqi territory, triggering mass displacement and severe humanitarian needs. After a military stalemate throughout much of 2015, government operations to retake territory from IS were stepped up in 2016 and are ongoing in 2017, aggravating displacement and humanitarian needs, such as health and WASH, particularly in Anbar and Mosul corridors.? Access constraints and human rights violations from all warring parties are of major concern.

Iraq now hosts three million IDPs, one of the largest internally displaced populations in the world.? IDPs and Syrian refugees make up 25% of the population in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I).?

INFORM measures Iraq’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.7/10 and 7/10 rates.?
IRQ.latest_developments_past: 09/07: The Old City of Mosul has been liberated from IS control by Iraqi Security Forces. The rate of returns is likely to increase in the coming weeks, and the threat of mines and ERW is a significant concern for returnees. Additionally, humanitarian needs in the area are very high, food and water are scarce, and prices are high and continuing to rise.??
IRQ.latest_developments_upcoming:
25/09: A referendum in KR-I will be held on independence. The Iraqi government in Baghdad, and Turkey oppose the referendum. ? ?

06/11: Legislative elections will be held in KR-I.?

JOR.main:
Jordan has the second highest per capita concentration of refugees worldwide. The latest estimates put the number of Syrian refugees at 1.3 million, of which roughly half are registered with UNHCR. ??   In addition, Jordan also hosts significant numbers of refugees from Palestine and Iraq, as well as other countries such as Sudan, Somalia, and Yemen.? ? The increase in population has put pressure on local infrastructure and services. Many refugees and vulnerable Jordanians live in substandard shelter, and have substantial food security, livelihoods, WASH, health, education and protection needs.

In addition to the refugee population inside Jordan, an estimated 85,000 Syrian refugees live in settlements around the Rukban and Hadalat border crossings between Syria and Jordan, referred to as The Berm. The border between the two countries has been closed or subject to very limited access since June 2016, due to a number of attacks by IS and other groups. Refugees at the berm lack access to food, shelter, WASH facilities, drinking water and medical care.?

INFORM measures Jordan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 3.8/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, however, at 6/10.?

KEN.main:
Drought was declared a national disaster in February 2017, as the number of people affected by acute food insecurity climbed from 700,000 in February 2016 to 3 million in March 2017. Most affected people are in arid and semi-arid lands, with conditions worst in Kilifi, Lamu, Marsabit, Tana River, and Turkana counties. The drought has deteriorated livestock conditions, water supplies, reduced harvests, and has caused conflict over resources.

New outbreaks have been reported in May in Nairobi, Vihiga, Mombasa, Murang'a, Kiambu, and in Kakuma and Kalobeyei camps in Turkana county.

Kenya also hosts a large some one of the largest  refugee populations in the world, just above 500,000, including over 300,000 from Somalia.

INFORM measures Kenya’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.1/10.?
KEN.latest_developments_past:
14/07: Nutrition in Turkana county is deteriorating, with SAM rates of 12% in Turkana South sub-county.?

12/07:  Atleast 10,000 people have been displaced by drought-related communal violence in Baringo and Laikipia counties. Shelter and food needs are high.?

08/07: 9 people were beheaded by Al Shabaab militants from Somalia in Jima area, Lamu county. This is an escalation of tactics by the militant group in the coastal regions of Kenya.?

KHM.main: Cambodia is facing its worst drought in 50 years, with water shortages being experienced in 18 out of the country's 25 provinces. Visit our Special reports section to read our latest briefing note.

LBN.main:
Lebanon has the highest per capita concentration of refugees worldwide, hosting more than 1.5 million Syrian refugees, 1.01 of whom are registered, as well as large populations of Palestinian refugees and Palestinian refugees from Syria. Tensions between host and refugee populations are increasing due to food price hikes, pressure on health and education systems, housing, employment, and legal documentation issues. Tensions between Lebanese authorities and the Joint Palestinian Security Forces have increased due to alleged infiltrations of armed groups in some camps. 

INFORM measures Lebanon’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.4/10. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.7/10.?

LBR.main:
Humanitarian needs in Liberia spiked in 2014 and 2015, when the Ebola epidemic caused a severe crisis throughout the country.

Liberia's baseline indicators (see Country Profile) provide an insight into the country's vulnerability to crisis.

LBY.main:
Libya is divided between three governments, each relying on local militias for territorial control. The country has been in a state of civil war since 2014, generating shortages of food, fuel, water, medical supplies and electricity, as well as reduced access to healthcare and public services. 

1.3 million people are in need of some form of humanitarian assistance. 

INFORM measures Libya's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.1/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 8.4/10 and 6.7/10 respectively.?
LBY.latest_developments_past:
10/07: The LNA made substantial advances in Benghazi. Islamist armed groups retain control of some buildings in its strongholds Soug al Hout and al Sabri. ?

09/07: Fighting between pro-GNA and pro-GNC forces has resumed on the eastern outskirts of Tripoli. ?

06/07: Conditions for migrants in Libya are worsening and include an increasing trend of physical violence against them, according to report.?
LBY.latest_developments_upcoming: 2017: The preliminary forecast for 2017 cereal crops is about 18% below average. This is mainly due to conflict and below-average rainfalls expected in some areas. ?

LKA.main:
Over 350,000 peopl have been affected by flooding – 200,000 have been evacuated to temporary shelters.

Click on "Special Reports" to read our latest briefing note on floods in Sri Lanka.

LSO.main:
Lesotho experienced severe drought due to below-average rainfall and high temperatures during the 2015/2016 El Niño. The weakening rand and increased food prices aggravated the humanitarian crisis.  Until early 2017, around one-quarter of the population was severely food insecure at Crisis (IPC Phase 3) conditions, with many people and services with only limited access to water.

Lesothowas categorised as No Severity in March 2017, as the food security situation improved significantly towards the end of 2016 and is expected to continue to improve in 2017 , with no severity in May 2017. The crisis analysis will no longer be updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Lesotho on a weekly basis, due to its vulnerability to food insecurity.
LSO.latest_developments_upcoming: FEWSNET predicts Lesotho will not have external food assistance needs in July 2017.

MDG.main:
Severe drought conditions have led to a third consecutive year of below-average food production, particularly in the south. Tsihombe, Ambovombe, and Bekily districts in Androy region are most affected: poor households are facing Crisis (IPC Phase 3) food security outcomes.

In the aftermath of Tropical Cyclone Enawo, which made landfall on the northeastern coast of Madagascar on 7 March, food and health needs have been rising in affected areas,  particularly in Antalaha and Maroantsetra districts.?

INFORM measures Madagascar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 5/10, compared to 4.9/10 in 2016. Madagascar's vulnerability is of concern, at 4.1/10.? ?
MDG.latest_developments_upcoming:
A below-average harvest of staple food cassava and sweet potato in July and August is expected. Food stocks will deplete earlier than usual and food access is expected to be significantly constrained by November 2016.

Food insecurity in 2017, in terms of magnitude and severity, is expected to increase as food insecure areas of the south approach the peak of the 2016/17 lean season between January and March 2017.

MKD.main: FYR Macedonia is on the route to western Europe for hundreds of thousands of people who are seeking asylum. ACAPS reports on the humanitarian situation among people in transit can be found under the Special Reports tab.

MLI.main:
Insecurity persists in northern and central Mali. Tensions between two of the signatories of the 2015 peace deal, the Azawad Movement Coalition (CMA) and the Groupe Autodéfense Touareg Imghad et Alliés (GATIA), periodically flare into conflict.  Attacks by Islamist armed groups, who are not part of the peace agreement, increased in 2016 and continued in 2017. 

Overall, a lack of access to basic social services and the low presence and capacity of public administration drives humanitarian needs. IDPs and refugees have slowly been returning home, but over 59,000 people remain internally displaced as of May 2017, and more than 140,000 refugees are still in neighbouring countries as of May 2017.?

INFORM measures Mali's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels, at 6.2/10, 6.8/10 and 6.7/10 respectively.?
MLI.latest_developments_past: 12/07: Armed groups that have signed the peace agreement in northern Mali clashed for the first time in months. Clashes occurred in Kidal region, killing at least 15 militants.

MMR.main:
Protracted armed conflict between ethnic groups and the government means over 525,500 people are in continued need of assistance, primarily in Kachin,  Rakhine states.?? Access to populations in need  in these states is constrained. There is active conflict primarily in Kachin, Shan and Rakhine states. .?

In Rakhine state, discrimination against the Rohingya Muslim minority has caused protracted displacement. IDPs in Rakhine have limited access to services and are confined to camps. Since October 2016, tensions between the Rohingya and the Myanmar Army have escalated and access has deteriorated further.?

INFORM measures Myanmar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.7/10. Hazard and exposure, as well as lack of coping capacity, and vulnerability are at 7.5/10, 6/10 and 6.6/10 respectively.?
MMR.latest_developments_past:
13/07: Flooding and heavy rain in Sagaing district has affected at least 10,830 people in 2,329 households, and 184 schools have been closed across eight townships as a safety precaution. An evacuation effort is underway.?

10/07: In Northern Rakhine state 80,500 children under five are expected to be in need of treatment for acute malnutrition within the comin 12 months. ?

MNG.main: The dzud - a phenomenon characterised by harsh winter conditions - put around 400,000 people in the northern and western Mongolia at risk of losing livestock and livelihoods in early 2016. See our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

MOZ.main:
On 4 May a truce between Renamo (Mozambique National Resistance) and Frelimo (Mozambique Liberation Front) was extended indefinitely and opposition leader Afonso Dhlakama stated that it signalled the beginning of the end of the war. INFORM measures Mozambique’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6/10. Mozambique’s lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 6.7/10.

Mozambique was categorised as No Severity in June 2017, as the food security situation improved and is expected to continue to improve in  the coming months. The nutritional situation has also improved. The crisis analysis will no longer be updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Mozambique on a weekly basis, due to its vulnerability to food insecurity.

MRT.main:
Mauritania has longstanding food security challenges, and severe levels of food insecurity are currently reported in pockets of the country (IPC Phases 3–4). This has contributed to 120,000 cases of malnutrition as of December 2017, most of which are in the south and eastern parts of the country.?

The number of refugees grew towards the end of 2016 as people fled violence in Mali, but has slowed in early 2017.?

INFORM measures Mauritania's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster in 2017 at 5.7/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 7/10. ?

MWI.main:
Drought has led to the most severe food crisis Malawi has faced in a decade: 6.7 million people (40% of the population) were expected to be food insecure in the November-March lean season. High food prices negatively impacted households as many had to purchase food to meet their needs. Cholera cases are reported across the country.

INFORM measures Malawi’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.8/10. Malawi’s lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 6.4/10 as well as vulnerability at 6.3/10.?
MWI.latest_developments_upcoming: Improved food security outcomes are expected to continue during the peak lean season. In the absence of humanitarian assistance, areas in central and southern Malawi would experience Crisis (IPC Phase 3) and Emergency (IPC Phase 4) outcomes.?

NAM.main: Namibia was categorised as No Severity in April 2017, as the food security situation improved significantly towards the end of 2016 and is expected to continue to improve in 2017 due to generous rainfalls across the country. The crisis analysis will no longer be updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Namibia on a weekly basis, due to its vulnerability to food insecurity.

NER.main:
Drought, floods, and epidemics in Niger frequently drive food security, nutrition, and health crises. Compounding this situation, and despite regional military efforts, Boko Haram (BH) attacks impact civilian populations along the Komadougou Yobe River and the shores of Lake Chad, and have caused extensive displacement.

Over 248,000 people are displaced in the Diffa region, including IDPs, returnees, and refugees from Nigeria.?The Diffa region, bordered by Chad and Nigeria, has been severely affected by Boko Haram’s sporadic attacks and military operations in the Lake Chad region. Despite the large number of humanitarian actors in Diffa, families living in sites for displaced people struggle to access sufficient water, food, and sanitation infrastructure.?1.9 million people are in need in Niger, including 340,000 people in Diffa region. Niger is also a transit country for migrants heading towards Europe. Some of them become stranded around Agadez and need protection assistance. ?

INFORM measures Niger's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 7.3/10, up from 5.6/10 in 2016. Niger's lack of coping capacity, measured at 7.8/10 is of particular concern.?
NER.latest_developments_past: 13/07: About 1,000 Nigeriens returnees from Chad in need of urgent basic humanitarian assistance in N'Guimi (Diffa region).?

NGA.main:
Violence in the northeast has caused massive displacement and at the same time restricted movement: it has disrupted food supplies, seriously hindered access to basic services, and limited agricultural activities. As of January 2017, it is estimated that 14 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, 8.5 million of whom are in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe states. Bauchi (2.8 million people), Gombe (1.4 million), and Taraba (1.3 million) also host high numbers of people in need. ?

In seven years of conflict, over 20,000 people have been killed in Boko Haram-related incidents. People affected by violence in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe, and neighbouring Bauchi, Taraba, and Gombe states are in urgent need of food, access to health services, protection, and education. Since February 2016, as humanitarian access is increasing, extreme food insecurity and malnutrition conditions have been revealed in Borno state.

INFORM measures Nigeria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster as 'high', 6.3/10, and its coping capacity index is 6.6/10. ?
NGA.latest_developments_past: 17/07: IDPs form Communal fighting and Returnees to Cross River state in recent weeks have created food and shelter needs across the region ??
NGA.latest_developments_upcoming:
The rainy season in the northeast, which began in May, is expected to cut off roads throughout the region, particularly near the Cameroonian border.

Shelter needs expected to increase with the onset of the rainy season from May onwards. 59 IDP camps are in high risk flooding areas. ?

NIC.main: In 2015, 500,000 people in the Central American “Dry Corridor”, covering El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua, were estimated to be facing severe food insecurity. An El Niño-related dry spell brought a second consecutive year of crop losses. See our Briefing Note in the Special Reports tab.

NPL.main:
On 25 April 2015, at 11:41 local time, an earthquake with of 7.8 magnitude hit Nepal. Its epicentre was 77km northwest of Kathmandu, and 68km east of Pokhara. More than 8,600 people died, 2.8 million were displaced, and in all more than 5 million people were affected by the disaster.

ACAPS supported the reporting of the humanitarian impact of the reponse. Weekly bulletins, thematic reports and district profiles were released and can be found here. Earlier and supplementary ACAPS reports can be found in the Special Reports tab.

PAK.main:
Around 3.2 million people are in need of humanitarian aid in Pakistan.? The security situation remains volatile due to militant attacks in urban centres and military operations against the Taliban in the tribal areas. Around 322,000 people remain displaced within Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and FATA.? Additionally around 1.42 million registered and around one million undocumented Afghans are living in Pakistan.? ?The needs of IDPs and Afghan refugees in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa are of particular concern. 

Aid agencies in Pakistan are struggling to deliver assistance because they lack government permission to operate. Attacks on NGO workers by armed groups also occur.??

INFORM measures Pakistan’s risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.6/10. Pakistan’s exposure to hazards is of particular concern, at 9/10.?
PAK.latest_developments_past: 05/07: Third polio case confirmed this year in Chaman, Balochistan.?

PER.main:
Peru is vulnerable to natural disasters. Heavy rains and flooding linked to the El Nino phenomenon has resulted in infrastructure damages, people evacuated and shelter needs countrywide in the past few years.

ACAPS published a report on floods in Peru on 22 March 2017.

PHL.main: The Philippines is at high risk of natural disasters. See the Special Reports tab for ACAPS analysis of recent cyclones and food security issues.

PNG.main: The country continues to recover from drought-related food insecurity, but following significant improvements in food insecurity it was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since 28 March, 2017. The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Papua New Guinea on a weekly basis, due to its underlying vulnerability and susceptibility to natural disasters.

PRK.main:
Humanitarian access remains extremely limited in DPRK, and very little information is available on the humanitarian situation. 18 million people, or 70% of the population, relies on the government's Public Distribution System (PDS) for their staple foods. In January 2017, the PDS provided 400g of barley, maize, rice, or wheat per person per day, which is insufficently diverse for healthy development and provides, even with the highest estimate, a caloric intake that is below basic nourishment requirements. ? ? DPRK is disaster-prone, regularly experiencing intense rain, floods, and droughts

INFORM measures DPRK's risk index as 5.6/10. The country also has poor coping capacity, with an estimated lack of coping capacity index of 6.9/10.  ?

PSE.main:
Ensuring the delivery of essential services including healthcare, food, water, and electricity remain of concern across the Gaza strip and the West Bank due to access restrictions imposed by Israel and neighbouring countries. Needs are particularly acute in Gaza, where around 65,000 Palestinians remain displaced from the 50-day war in 2014. The ongoing blockade continues to severely restrict the delivery of services and the movement of people and goods.

INFORM measures Palestine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 to be at 4.8/10, down from 6.1/10 in 2016. Vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.3/10.?

RWA.main: Rwanda is impacted by the crisis in Burundi, as it hosts refugees fleeing violence. See the Special Reports tab for more information.

SDN.main: Protracted insurgencies are being waged by armed groups across Darfur, and persistent conflict situations in South Kordofan and Blue Nile cause high levels of insecurity. Darfur has been the scene of conflict for over a decade, while violence in Blue Nile and South Kordofan increased significantly after South Sudan gained independence in 2011.  Humanitarian access to conflict zones is severely restricted and remains so despite efforts of the AU and UN to broker a peace agreement and ensure increased humanitarian access.  Violence, food insecurity, malnutrition, and lack of access to basic services have ca used large-scale internal displacement.  According to INFORM, Sudan is at high risk of being overwhelmed by humanitarian crises and disasters (7/10). Hazard, vulnerability, and a lack of coping capacity are at alarming rates of 7.4/10, 6.6/10, and 7/10
SDN.latest_developments_past: 08/07: At least 120,000 people are experiencing Emergency (IPC Phase 4) levels of food insecurity in SPLM-N controlled areas of South Kordofan and in areas of Jebel Marra in Darfur. ?

SEN.main:
Livelihoods have been affected by both floods and rainfall deficits in northern and western Senegal. Floods between July and September 2016 directly affected up to 20,000 people, destroying many agricultural stocks and threatening livelihoods. ? ??

Senegal scores 5.1/10 on the INFORM index 2017, a rise from 4.3 last year. ?

SLE.main: Sierra Leone was the subject of a number of ACAPS reports covering the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, see the Special Reports tab. Baseline data can be found in the Country Profile.

SLV.main:
INFORM measures El Salvador's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 3.5/10. Lack of coping capacity is of particular concern, at 4.7/10.?

The country is recovering from drought since 2015, and was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview since mid-December. The crisis analysis is no longer updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor El Salvador on a weekly basis, due to its gang violence and underlying vulnerability.

SOM.main:
Drought effects stretching back to 2014 were aggravated by a severe El Niño in 2016, increasing the impact in 2017, including possible famine. More than half the population, some 6 million people, are in need of humanitarian assistance. Drought has affected food and water supplies, leading to a major food security and nutrition crisis as well as widespread measles and cholera outbreaks. Some 600,000 people have been displaced due to drought between November 2016 and mid-April 2017, with most joining existing IDP camps, where needs are high. 

Famine is possible in 2017 if humanitarian assistance is inadequate – a key concern given access remains extremely limited outside of Somaliland: Lower and Middle Juba regions are particularly inaccessible due to the Al Shabaab insurgency.  The government's control is essentially limited to Mogadishu and surrounding areas, although Al Shabaab attacks in the city persist.

The INFORM index score for risk of humanitarian catastrophe ranks Somalia at 9.2 out of 10, the highest of any country.
SOM.latest_developments_past: 05/07: 132 street children abandoned the Mogadishu Rehabilitation and feeding centre in Abdiaziz district, Banadir region, due to lack of food.?

SRB.main:
A cold wave hit Serbia in January 2017. ACAPS short note can be found here.

Serbia is on the route for refugees and migrants heading to western Europe. ACAPS produced a number of Briefing Notes on the situation as part of a project in 2015–2016.

A report on heavy flooding in the Balkan countries in May 2014 is also available here.

SSD.main:
Since the beginning of 2017, clashes between government and opposition forces are reported in Upper Nile, Jonglei, Central and Eastern Equatoria, and Western Bahr el Ghazal, causing widespread human rights violations, large scale internal displacement and refugee outflow towards Sudan and Uganda. Violence against aid workers has escalated, hampering aid delivery in conflict-affected areas.

Famine was declared in southern parts of Unity state at the end of February, and food security is expected to further deteriorate at the height of the lean season in July. Critical malnutrition levels are reported in Unity, Western Equatoria, Western Bahr el Ghazal, Eastern Equatoria and Jonglei. This is compounded by an ongoing cholera outbreak notably in Lakes and Jonglei. The extended rainy season from April to October is likely to accelerate the spread of the disease. 

INFORM measures South Sudan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster for 2017 to be extremely high, at 8.8/10, an increase from 8.3/10 in 2016. South Sudan's vulnerability is measured at 9/10
SSD.latest_developments_past:
12/07: Three UNICEF sub-contractors were allegedly detained by opposition forces last week in Pagak, Upper Nile, following a government offensive on opposition strongholds. The opposition denied the accusations.? Access to affected populations remains limited. 

11/07: In June, 46 incidents involving violence against humanitarian personnel and assets were recorded, up from 29 in May. 100 humanitarian access incidents were reported overall in June, the highest number so far in 2017.?

09/07: Bor youth association in Jonglei called for the evacuation of Equatorian aid workers in response to alleged killings of Dinkas in the Equatorias?

07/07: An estimated 50,000 people are cut off from assistance in Upper Nile’s Longochuk and Maiwut counties following a government offensive. At least 25 aid workers were relocated from Pagak and surrounding areas. Humanitarian compounds were looted in Mathiang.?

SVN.main: Slovenia is on the route through the Balkans for people seeking asylum in western Europe. ACAPS reports on the humanitarian situation for migrants and refugees in transit can be found under the Special Reports tab.

SWZ.main:
The country experienced significant reductions in crop production in 2016 as a result of El Niño, a situation that worsened food security in 2017. As a result, 492,454 people required food assistance.?The government of Swaziland declared a national drought disaster in February 2016. INFORM evaluates Swaziland's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be moderate at 3.1/10. Swaziland's lack of coping capacity is of particular concern at 5.6/10.

Swaziland was categorised as No Severity in June 2017, as the food security situation improved and is expected to continue to improve in  the coming months. The crisis analysis will no longer be updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Swaziland on a weekly basis, due to its underlying vulnerability.

SYR.main:
14.9 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Syria, including 6.3 million IDPs.

Conflict has killed over 324,000 people, including 87,000 civilians, and caused large-scale displacement. Protection concerns are widespread. WASH and access to food are high priorities, as well as access to health services. Humanitarian needs in areas under prolonged and ongoing siege are particularly high as access is obstructed.

Clashes are ongoing in Dara, ar Raqqa, Homs, and Hama governorates and Deir Ezzor city. The Turkish army recently increased activity in Aleppo governorate, targeting both Islamic State and the Kurdish YPG. 

INFORM measures Syria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. The intensity of highly violent conflict in the country is of particular concern . ?
SYR.latest_developments_past:
10/07: The ceasefire agreed by the US and Russia across southern Syria is largely holding, except for clashes in Suweida, where the government alleges it is fighting IS, and minor breaches in Dara and Quneitra.?

06/07: Anecdotal evidence from Raqqa city highlights WASH needs: the water system is non-functional and sewage facilities destroyed. Cases of waterborne diseases are on the rise. The population halved in two weeks, as people move to safer areas.?

TCD.main:
Over 4.7 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Chad, including nearly 900,000 people expected to be food insecure across the country in June.  As of 30 June, more than 118,800 Chadian IDPs and over 8,700 refugees from Chad are displaced in the Lake Chad region.?The country faces security threats on its periphery, most notably from Boko Haram (BH) since February 2015 in Lac region. Attacks have targeted both military operations and civilians, driving people from their homes. Around 130,000 people are displaced in Lac region. Nigerian refugees have been crossing into Chad since 2014, further adding to large refugee populations from Sudan in the east, and Central African Republic in the south.

Underlying vulnerability and food insecurity is high, particularly in the Sahelian zone to the north of the country.

INFORM measures Chad's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 7.76/10, up from 6 in 2016. Hazard and exposureVulnerability as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at 7.2.4/10 and 8.99/10.? ?
TCD.latest_developments_past: 12/07: Increased insecurity incidents in Kangalom state affecting humanitarian access to returnees.?

TJK.main:
As of mid-2016, 715,000 people were in need of assistance in rural central and eastern parts of the country. This was mainly due the deteriorating economic situation in Russia and restrictions on the migrant labour market, which affected Tajik purchasing power by reducing the frequency and volume of remittances, used by many households to buy food.

As of early 2017, the food security situation improved with the increased volume and frequency of remittances due to Russia’s strengthened economy. The situation is expected to continue to improve in the next months. Therefore, as of May 2017, Tajikistan was categorised as No Severity. The crisis analysis will no longer be updated, but ACAPS continues to monitor Tajikistan on a weekly basis, due to its vulnerability to food insecurity. 

INFORM measures Tajikistan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium at 4.4/10.?

TLS.main: The drought induced by El Niño is reported on in an ACAPS Briefing Note of April 2016. Analysis of the country's preparedness is also available under the Special Reports tab.

TUR.main:
Turkey hosts over 2.9 million Syrian refugees, who are  in need of food and livelihood support, and shelter assistance.

Tensions between government forces and Kurdish separatists escalated in July 2015.  Clashes and bomb attacks occur mostly in the southeast, but occasionally in Istanbul and Ankara. Curfews limit access to affected areas, and hundreds of thousands of people have been internally displaced. Widespread destruction of shelter has been reported.

Tens of thousands of people have been arrested, detained, or dismissed since a failed coup in July 2016. Media freedom and the independence of the judiciary are of concern. The crackdown on pro-Kurdish political parties has escalated since September 2016. 

INFORM measures Turkey's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 5.0/10. Hazard and exposure is of particular concern, at a 7.8/10 rate.?
TUR.latest_developments_past: 04/07: Ten human rights activists, including the local director of Amnesty International have been arrested for alleged participation in a terrorist organisation.?

UGA.main:
Uganda currently hosts over 1.3 million refugees and asylum seekers from neighboring countries, including more than 970,000 from South Sudan.  The high numbers have increasingly strained the humanitarian response in Uganda. ??

Poor rainfall from March to May and an armyworm outbreak will reduce harvests in the middle of 2017, leading to increased food insecurity outcomes in the country.

INFORM measures Uganda's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.9/10. Lack of coping capacity is of concern, at 6.9/10. ?

UKR.main:
Eastern Ukraine has been in a humanitarian crisis since March 2014, when armed conflict erupted between separatists and Ukrainian armed forces. Separatists now control most of eastern Donetsk region, and a small area of southern Luhansk region. 3.8 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance and more than 2.8 million have been displaced. Protection and health are of particular concern in conflict areas, particularly as a large number of older people are affected. Humanitarian access is constrained: virtually all international aid organisations (all in Donestk) have been banned from non-government areas. ? However, in September 2016 UNHCR’s license to operate in Donetsk and surrounding areas was renewed. ?

INFORM measures Ukraine's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 5.3/10. Hazard exposure rating is also very high at 7/10.?

VEN.main: By February 2016, Venezuela had reported over 4,500 confirmed cases of Zika virus. However, unofficial estimates were thought to be as high as 400,000. ACAPS Briefing Note on the Zika outbreak across Latin America and the Caribbean can be found under the Special Reports tab. Most recent ACAPS Briefing Note on the humanitarian situation in Venezuela as of May 2017 can also be found under the Special Reports tab.

YEM.main:
20.7 million people are in need of humanitarian aid, including 9.8 million people in acute need. Fighting escalated in March 2015, and an armed advance on the capital in September 2014 by Houthis from the north triggered a civil war throughout the country.?? A coalition of Arab states led by Saudi Arabia is supporting the Yemeni government with airstrikes. Activities by southern secessionists, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) and Islamic State (IS) compound the security and political challenges.? The economy is also failing, with the Central Bank near collapse. ?

The Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) declared Yemen a Level 3 emergency in July 2015. INFORM measures Yemen's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at a very high level of 7.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels: 8.2/10, 7.9/10 and 7.8/10 respectively.?
YEM.latest_developments_past: 08/07: The cholera outbreak that began on 27 April has now killed more than 1,700 people. 297,000 suspected cases have been reported in all governorates with the exception of Socotra. The lack of good quality, reliable drinking water sources is forcing people to get water from unsafe alternative sources, perpetuating the cholera crisis.?

ZMB.main:
The country continues to recover from drought-related food insecurity, but following significant improvements most of the country is now experiencing Minimal (IPC Phase 1) levels of food insecurity. Therefore, it was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview as of 9 May 2017. While the crisis analysis is no longer updated, ACAPS continues to monitor Zambia on a weekly basis due to its underlying vulnerability.?

INFORM measures Zambia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be medium, at 4.1/10. Lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are of particular concern at 6.1/10 and 5.3/10, respectively.

ZWE.main: The country continues to recover from drought-related food insecurity and following significant improvements most of the country is now experiencing Minimal (IPC Phase 1) levels of food insecurity, except for some vulnerable areas experiencing Stressed (IPC Phase 2) levels. Water availability for domestic, livestock , and other livelihood uses has also improved. Therefore, it was categorised as No Severity in the Global Emergency Overview as of 11 July 2017. While the crisis analysis is no longer updated, ACAPS continues to monitor Zimbabwe on a weekly basis due to its underlying vulnerability.
